metadata.subject: White Collar Titan Reid Weingarten on Juries, Clients and the Scariest Federal Prosecutors

relationships.description: Extremely close friends, grew up together in Justice Department, like family

transactions: Bob Strauss gave $1 million to foundation
assets: building on Ninth Street in Shaw neighborhood

analysis.purpose: To provide insights into Reid Weingarten's career as a white-collar defense attorney and his philanthropic work
analysis.significance: Reveals strategies and philosophy of one of America's top defense lawyers, including jury selection tactics and case assessment

notable_quotes: 'The ratio is probably two-thirds lawyer, one-third shrink.'

'When prosecutors are striking all the lawyers and accountants and college-educated people... what they want is to rely on visceral hatred for the target and also a visceral reliance on Uncle Sam, as opposed to the facts.'
'The pain of a defeat is much greater than the joy of victory. I don't know why that isâ€”I wish it were otherwise.'

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this professional interview

illegal_activity.description: This is a news article interview discussing legal defense work and past cases, not evidence of first-hand illegal activity

details: Interview with Jenna Greene of The Litigation Daily

public_knowledge.context: This is a published news article from a legal publication, intended for public consumption about a prominent attorney's career

analysis.summary: This is a published interview with prominent white-collar defense attorney Reid Weingarten discussing his legal strategies, high-profile clients, jury selection techniques, and his co-founding of the See Forever Foundation for juvenile offenders with Eric Holder Jr.
